sentences.text: On Windows, we currently create desktop shortcuts the following way:
"X:\Path\To\chrome.
exe" --app=<URL>

We filter <URL> for 0x20, 0x09, 0x0a, 0x0b, 0x0d, etc, but we otherwise let
most other data indiscriminately.

One of the characters that is not
filtered is % (e.
g.
, stray % will not be encoded as %25 or removed).

This
permits a shortcut such as:
"X:\Path\To\chrome.
exe"
--app=http://example.com/%some_env_variable%--renderer-path=/something/else/entirely

to be created if the user is duped into clicking "Create application
shortcut" on a malicious page.
This syntax will be substituted by Windows prior to launching chrome.
exe.
If %some_env_variable% happens to end with a whitespace, things go bad.
To fix: ideally, I would recommend a different syntax, such as:
"X:\Path\To\chrome.
exe" --launch-in-app-mode -- http://example.
com/.

This is much more robust (we could still support the --app syntax for
legacy shortcuts).

If we feel it is too late to change the syntax, however, we should at the
very minimum, be more pedantic about escaping here.

I would also recommend escaping characters such as ", \, etc, as their
effect on Windows shell parsing is unclear to me, I don't think it's
well-documented anywhere, and if they actually legitimately appear in an
URL, the URL will be corrupted.

I did some quick tests on Linux, but don't see an obvious way to break it
there (we escape `, $, ", etc).

And by the way, I couldn't find any variable that ends in a whitespace to exploit it
(e.
g.

, no $IFS-equivalent) - but I'm not really that much of a Windows guru, there
might be something.

This works on Vista if you have an environment variable ending in a space, which you 
don't have by default.
(%CMDCMDLINE% ends in a space if you just run cmd.

exe without 
arguments, but it's not set outside of cmd.
exe, so you can't use that).

I tried "%ProgramFiles:~10,1%" (it'll extract 1 character at offset 10, which is 
normally the space between "program" and "files") but that also does not work outside 
of cmd.
exe.

You can use "%ProgramFiles%" but that leaves you with a second argument 
starting with "files", which doesn't seem to provide any attack vector.

I also noticed you can insert "&" which normally separates commands in windows, so 
I've tried "http://www.
example.
com/&c:\windows\system32\calc.

exe" but the & doesn't 
seem to get used as a command separator at all and the entire URL is parsed to 
Chrome, so no attack there.
All in all, we should fix this because it is exploitable.

However, I don't think many 
users are at risk (if any) because there is no common environment variable ending 
with a space.
We just received an external report of this.

The reporter focuses on the fact it could 
lead to information disclosure (e.
g.

, system type or user name via env variables), 
although this is a very remote risk.
Adding the reporter - Inferno - to the cc: list, as per his request.
SecSeverity-Low since this requires a range of user interactions.
However, this got noticed externally so we should see what can be done.
Is anyone working on this?
Any ideas for a suitable assignee?
Fixing for the v4 release would be nice.
We should find an owner :) Marking M4.

I'll send out a mail with all M4 security bugs 
once I've done the triage.

@lcamtuf: if we escape % -> %25, will Windows look for an environment variable 
starting with the name "25" ?

Does Windows have any quote characters which will desist it from doing env var 
expansion within those quotes?

Escaping % -> %25 is tricky, because you don't want, say, %3E in an URL becoming 
%253E.

We could escape everything that does not match %[a-fA-F0-9]{2}; this may still 
permit %aardvark% to go through, but looking at my windows box, I don't see any 
standard variables that would start with this pattern.

Some obscure application-
specific ones probably exist on certain installations.
Another option would be to just base64-encode shortcut URLs.

This makes them opaque, 
so users may be not too happy; or double-escape or otherwise encode % (but then, this 
will cause problems with manually inspecting and tweaking such targets).
I don't know of a way to prevent substitution by prefixing % with something :-(

As noted earlier, I am also not entirely sure that Windows shell expansion is that 
well-studied (and it's definitely very quirky and makes several things inherently 
insecure), so regardless of the fix we employ to minimize the risk of information 
disclosure, it may make sense to tweak the calling convention to prevent potentially 
more serious parameter splitting issues.
D:\>set 25=a
D:\>echo %25%
a
So, yes.
But:
I think that only works from shell, not from shortcuts, though.

one idea I have is to store length of url when creating the shortcut (like 
25,http://.

When chrome launches the shortcut, it validates the length to see if 
the OS has not expanded the shortcut with the env variable values (can decide to 
raise a warning/not execute the shortcut at all).

this solution might work for other 
OS flavors as well.

one small issue with this when a env variable like %USERNAME% has 
value lcamtuf007 , in that case, length of final url matches the initial url.

But 
this can be easily fixed by storing no of non alphanumeric characters in url as well.
so, shortcut will have something like --app=length,no of non alpha chars,http://url

Michal's solution is nice since no OOTB env variables in windows don't have that 
pattern (user defined env variable will be a very targeted attack with minor use 
cases).
haven't checked if env variable values get substituted in linux flavors.

@lcamtuf you're right; I tried various potential meta character but couldn't find 
anything that would be triggered by CreateProcess;
C:\Windows\System32\notepad.
exe %userprofile%\^%username^%.

txt
opens ^%username^%.
txt
C:\Windows\System32\notepad.
exe %userprofile%\%%username%%.

txt
opens %maruel%.
txt
Sadness.

Sorry I'm jumping in on the tail of this discussion, but here are a few points to 
remember:

* The loader (e.g. CreateProcess) does not expand environment variables. They must be 
explicitly expanded by the executable.
* The shortcut handler (the shell extension that handles *.

lnk files) explicitly 
expands environment variables because they may be embedded in paths; that's why 
Chrome appears to be getting them implicitly expanded.
* The command shell (cmd.

exe) is the only part of Windows that provides escape 
characters; it also expands environment variables before passing them to an 
executable via the command line.
So, the shrotcut handler is expanding environment variables and doing nothing else.

Unfortunately, it provides no way of disabling expansion, or escaping the percent 
character.

That's why there's basically no good solution to this problem using 
shortcuts.
So, how about not using shortcuts?

We can create a new file type with the URL and any 
other startup parameters (probably just in a JSON dictionary).

On installation of 
Chrome we create an association with the file type that starts Chrome with the 
appropriate switches.

Then we just read the URL and startup parameters out of that 
file.

So, we get something that behaves like a shortcut, but avoids the environment 
expansion mess with the shortcut handler.

Other than that, the only option I see is to come up with a different escape sequence 
for the percent character.

It might look ugly, but it would prevent unintended 
environment variable expansion.

Of course, that's not much different than lcamtuf's 
suggestion of base64 encoding the entire URL.
Oops, I didn't see the m4 tag there.
So, push my other suggestion to after m4.

For now, I think the best we can do is escape any percent character that doesn't 
match a URL escape sequence, which will prevent expansion of any default variables.

We should also quote the entire URL string to prevent injecting additional arguments 
to Chrome (and ensure the quotes are URL encoded).

We already use 
CommandLineToArgvW() in our command processor, so it will parse the quotes around the 
URL without any additional modification.
cevans@, if you want I can write a patch that does this today.

As for the impact in the current code, I don't see anything other than environment 
leakage and a very longshot chance at argument injection to Chrome if you can find an 
environment variable to work with.

There's no chance of shell metacharacter expansion 
or code execution since the command line never goes through the shell.
How about we encode/decode both "%" and "\" using "\x.
" encoding?

That type of hex 
encoding characters is common in other places (eg.

JavaScript) and existing links are 
unlikely to contain "\x" afaik, so this is will cause very limitted breakage.
I'm grabbing this.
My solution is:
1. URL encode unsafe characters including whitespace and: <>{}[]|\^~`"'
2. Replace any occurrences of % in the string with the \
3. Wrap the URL in double quotes

The replacement character is URL encoded from the source string, so it never occurs 
in output string.
The quotes prevent argument injection and will get parsed by CommandLineToArgvW().
Then we just replace \ with % to get back to the correct URL.
This seems like the easiest and safest option, unless someone has a better idea.
Ugly, but should be good enough :p
\ is not encoded in the url paramater value (verified in 4.

43), so it will mess 
up the % replacements with \ :(.

plus, it would be unreadable to user if user tries to 
see shortcut properties.
e.
g.
http://www.
merriam-webster.
com/dictionary/secure?
abc=def\
sorry forgot to see that you are url encoding the unsafe chars first.

please ignore 
last comment.
Should be backwards compatible too.
Useful :)

Strictly speaking, this may cause problems; {, }, ^, ~, [, ], `, etc are reserved 
characters in URLs, and encoding them may change the meaning of the URL to 
implementations that rely on this (much like replacing / with %2F makes a difference 
to most webservers).
As a quick kludge, I think this is acceptable, though.

Alternatively, you may do 
something like replacing \, %, and other problematic characters with \xNN (and then 
decode this on load).

This is less likely to cause interference, and about as 
complicated.

One more thing: we probably don't want to decode \-encoded URLs when invoked from a 
place other than a shortcut (which can be inferred from cmdline switches).

I agree with lcamtuf so maybe I wasn't clear before: I suggest replacing problematic 
chars (\"<>|&%, everything < 0x20 or >= 0x7F) with "\x"-encoded values in the 
shortcut URL and decode them before opening the page, as in:
C:\Path\To\Chrome.
exe --app="http://example.
com/\x5C\x22\x3C\x3E\x7C\x26\x25"
Will cause Chrome to open this url:
http://example.

I suggest using "\x" rather than just "\" as the chance of having "\x" in existing 
application shortcuts is smaller; so we would break less existing shortcuts when we 
introduce this feature.

(Unless you also want to write a tool that finds all existing 
shortcuts and apply this new encoding to them when the user installs a new version of 
Chrome).

@lcamtuf - The decoding is part of processing the --launch-in-app-mode switch, so it 
won't be done anywhere else.

Also, I can reduce the set of encoded characters; I just 
wanted to start broadly and see how it worked.
@skylined - I understood your suggested escape sequence.

I just thinks it's more 
awkward to stack two forms of encoding in the same string.

My suggestion is simple 
URL encoding, but replacing the % escape character with \ to avoid environment 
variable expansion.
Consider the following: http://example.
com/The%20Test\
\ substitution: http://example.
com/The\20Test\5c
\x encoding:    http://example.
com/The\x2520Test\x5c
Personally, I think the the first one is just clearer.

If you guys disagree, though, 
we can go with the \x encoding.

Justin: I wasn't suggesting narrowing down the character set, just collapsing steps 2 
and 3 into a single step: instead of first %nn-escaping undesirable characters, and 
then switching % to \ (which may interfere with URL semantics, because when you 
replace \ back with %, you end up with a different URL still), you can simply have a 
list of "bad" characters that includes % and \, and encode them as \xNN or \NN, thus 
preserving the underlying URL as-is.
Michal: My rationale is that we already get URLs with % encoded characters in them.

So, 
I was trying to avoid double-encoded strings like \x2520.

Perhaps I'm making to much of 
an issue of that, but the double encoding just seems unnecessarily ugly.

As for URL semantics, I'm sticking to a subset of the "unwise" characters defined in 
RFC 2396.

Escaping is recommended for those, and I'm not touching any of the reserved 
characters.

Also, this escaping is Windows only, so I don't have to mess with the Unix 
shell characters.
Ah OK, carry on then :p
(No comment was entered for this change.
